case_title: Kh. GHULAM QADIR vs AZAD GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF JAMMU AND KASHMIR
court: Azad Jammu and Kashmir Service Tribunal
respondant: Azad Government of the State of Jammu and Kashmir

accussed_details.name: Kh. GHULAM QADIR
allegation: Claim for pay scale upgrade to B.P.S. 20

complaint_summary: The appellant claimed entitlement to pay scale B.P.S. 20 for his tenure as Registrar, Judicial Board/Supreme Court, citing parity with similar positions in Pakistan.
investigation_summary: The appellant's promotion and appointment as Registrar were reviewed, including government orders and relevant statutes. The appellant was promoted to District and Sessions Judge after his appointment as Registrar.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal dismissed the appeal, ruling that the appellant was not entitled to pay scale B.P.S. 20 as he was not a confirmed District and Sessions Judge at the time of his appointment as Registrar. The principle of parity was deemed inapplicable due to the lack of requisite qualifications.
legal_arguments: Appellant argued entitlement to B.P.S. 20 based on parity with Pakistan's Supreme Court Registrar.
Respondent argued appellant was not qualified as a confirmed District and Sessions Judge at the time of appointment.
statutes: Azad Jammu and Kashmir Service Tribunals Act, 1975
Azad Jammu and Kashmir Interim Constitution Act, 1974
sections: Section 4 of Azad Jammu and Kashmir Service Tribunals Act, 1975
citations: P L D 1971 Azad J & K 118
key_issues: Confirmation as District and Sessions Judge

maxims.Equality before law: The principle of parity must be applied consistently and equitably.

legal_terms.Parity: Equal treatment in pay and allowances for similar positions.

words_and_phrases.Confirmed District and Sessions Judge: A judicial officer who has completed probation and is officially confirmed in the position.

summary_vector_notes: The appellant's claim for pay scale upgrade was based on parity with Pakistan's Supreme Court Registrar. The Tribunal dismissed the appeal, citing lack of requisite qualifications and conditions for parity application. The appellant's promotion to District and Sessions Judge was conditional and did not meet the criteria for pay scale B.P.S. 20.
